questions.question_text: An Administrator is configuring Authentication Enforcement and they would like to create an exemption rule to exempt a specific group from authentication. Which authentication enforcement object should they select?

discussion.content:

A is correct

Selected Answer: A
default-browser-challenge—The firewall transparently obtains user authentication credentials
 
default-web-form—To authenticate users, the firewall uses the certificate profile or authentication profile you specified when configuring Authentication Portal
 
default-no-captive-portal—The firewall evaluates Security policy without authenticating users.

Selected Answer: A
A

no captive portal - is a correct option to bypass auth rules

Correct: A

questions.question_text:
A bootstrap USB flash drive has been prepared using a Linux workstation to load the initial configuration of a Palo Alto Networks firewall. The USB flash drive was formatted using file system ntfs and the initial configuration is stored in a file named init-cfg.txt.
The contents of init-cfg.txt in the USB flash drive are as follows:
//IMG//

The USB flash drive has been inserted in the firewalls' USB port, and the firewall has been powered on. Upon boot, the firewall fails to begin the bootstrapping process. The failure is caused because:

discussion.content:
As per PA it will support FAT32 and ext3 so the correct ans is E ( Unsupported File System ) 

The USB flash drive that bootstraps a hardware-based Palo Alto Networks firewall must support one of the
following:
• File Allocation Table 32 (FAT32)
• Third Extended File System (ext3)
Correct answer is E - Unsupported File System

Selected Answer: E
E is correct
The question states that the USB was already formatted using ntfs, which is unsupported. E is correct.

Selected Answer: E
E is correct
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-admin/firewall-administration/bootstrap-the-firewall/usb-flash-drive-support
The USB flash drive that bootstraps a hardware-based Palo Alto Networks firewall must support one of the following:
File Allocation Table 32 (FAT32)
Third Extended File System (ext3)

Selected Answer: C
The correct answer is C.
For bootstraping the USB must be in ext4 format
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/firewall-administration/bootstrap-the-firewall/bootstrap-a-firewall-using-a-usb-flash-drive
Because all Linux users always use NTFS :-D

Selected Answer: E
File name should be init-cfg.txt (not xml) (B is incorrect)
Config looks fine according to:
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/firewall-administration/bootstrap-the-firewall/sample-init-cfgtxt-files (D is not correct)
option A - looks stupid
Supported file systems ext3 and FAT32, so it should be E
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/firewall-administration/bootstrap-the-firewall/usb-flash-drive-support
Correct "E" File system is ext3 or fat32

Selected Answer: E
Filesystems supported are ext3, fat32
Should be E

comments.content:

questions.question_text:
To more easily reuse templates and template stacks, you can create template variables in place of firewall-specific and appliance-specific IP literals in your configurations.
Which one is the correct configuration?
Decrypted packets from the website https://www.microsoft.com will appear as which application and service within the Traffic log?

discussion.content:
Made an account just to tell you guys the correct answer is A.

Application is first identified as SSL on port 443, then decrypted, then identified as web-browsing on port 443. Application identification changes due to app shift, but the port number doesn't!

Correct answer is A.

comments.content: no, since ssl forward proxy is in place. ssl is getting "decrypted", and traffic is identified as web-browsing. app-id will be ssl initially but *shift*!

discussion.content:
The answer should be C.... Application - HTTPS = SSL, HTTP = Web Browsing.......Service-
SSL=443, Web-Browsing=80

Selected Answer: A
A. web-browsing and 443

Explanation:

When traffic to https://www.microsoft.com is decrypted by a Palo Alto Networks firewall:

Application: The decrypted traffic is classified as web-browsing (since it’s HTTP/HTTPS web traffic).
Service/Port: The original encrypted traffic uses port 443 (HTTPS), and this port is retained in the logs even after decryption.
Why Not the Other Options?

B. SSL and 80 → Incorrect. Port 80 is for HTTP (unencrypted), and "SSL" is not the app name after decryption.
C. SSL and 443 → "SSL" is the application name before decryption. Once decrypted, it becomes web-browsing.
D. web-browsing and 80 → Port 80 is for HTTP, but Microsoft’s site uses HTTPS (port 443).
Key Notes:

Before decryption: App = ssl, Port = 443.
After decryption: App = web-browsing, Port = 443 (retained from original flow).
Thus, A is correct for decrypted packets.

Selected Answer: A
As the question asks about the application after packet decryption, it will see the application as Web-Browsing with port 443.

Selected Answer: A
As mentioned before, application is identified as ssl and then web browsing after decryption.

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A.
A, apparently.
Option A is correct.

Selected Answer: A
After being decrypted, the traffic is web-browsing traffic / port 443.
Before being decrypted, the traffic is ssl traffic / port 443.

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer: A. After a packet is decrypted we see web browsing in logs.
Correct answer is A

Selected Answer: A
If its decrypted than it will know that APP-ID = Web-Browsing and port 443 - SO A for sure

It is definitely "A". Just looked it up on a firewall:

vsys1 104.208.16.90[443]/def00 (104.208.16.90[443])

and looking more closely:
show session id 20714

Session 20714

 proto: 6
 sport: 63325 dport: 443
...
 application : web-browsing
...
 tracker stage firewall : TCP FIN
 tracker stage l7proc : proxy timer expired
 end-reason : tcp-fin

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer is A.

Correct answer is A.

Answer is A because the question is about decrypted traffic logs and after app-shift it is web-browsing. And dont worry about the port 443, as it doesnt change during decryption and 443 is one of the standard port for web0browsing in new Pan-OS.
Also if you have encountered app as SSL even after decryption refer this link for explanation: https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000Cle8CAC
Correct Ans is A : I just tested in LAB; port 443 and application - web-browsing
only A
Panos 9.1 and up webbrowing application has port 80 and 443. Correct answer will be A

A seems to be the correct answer since SSL traffic is encrypted and the firewall is decrypting it. SSL will be changed to webbrowsing (that generally uses port 80) but in later versions of the PanOS (above 9), web-browsing also comes with a secure port field that shows its secure port as 443. This is to facilitate automatic categorization in ssl decryption.
Link below:

https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000CmdLCAS

comments.content: no, this is not true, the app is SSL for 443 and web-browsing is 80 ...

discussion.content:
Answer A
Application will be web-browsing which is obvious and it's over port 443 since that's default for https
correct Answer is A

You guys know that SSL/HTTPS traffic is just web-browsing/HTTP traffic over an SSL tunnel. We all agree that traffic comes to the FW as SSL traffic on port 443, however as the question says, the traffic is already decrypted by the FW, which means is no longer over SSL encryption and therefore becomes web-browsing traffic, but the port never changes. So the traffic decrypted is seen as web-browsing using port 443

A is correct. 

Decryption does not modify any ports. It simply decrypts the packet. 

Since the question states "decrypted" packets. The traffic will appear as "web-browsing" for application and "ssl/443" as the service. 

If traffic were not decrypted, it would appear as "ssl" and "443".
web-browsing has; http=tcp/80 and https=tcp/443 so why wouldnt it be web-browsing.....this is on PAN-OS

Correct Answer: C
Application: SSL Service Port : 443
Application: Web-browsing Service Port: 80

questions.question_text: On the NGFW, how can you generate and block a private key from export and thus harden your security posture and prevent rogue administrators or other bad actors from misusing keys?

choices.B: 1. Select Device > Certificates 2. Select Certificate Profile 3. Generate the certificate 4. Select Block Private Key Export
choices.C: 1. Select Device > Certificate Management > Certificates > Device > Certificates 2. Generate the certificate 3. Select Block Private Key Export 4. Click Generate to generate the new certificate
choices.A: 1. Select Device > Certificate Management > Certificates > Device > Certificates 2. Import the certificate 3. Select Import Private key 4. Click Generate to generate the new certificate
choices.D: 1. Select Device > Certificates 2. Select Certificate Profile 3. Generate the certificate 4. Select Block Private Key Export
